awd_titl_txt: ASCEND: Expanding the Multi-Messenger Impact of In-Ice Radio Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
Marco Muzio is awarded an NSF Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the Pennsylvania State University.  Muzio will use multi-messenger astronomy, combining neutrino, gamma-ray, and particle detection to study the highest energy events. Specifically, Muzio will use data from the Askaryan Radio Array (ARA) to perform new, higher sensitivity studies related to very high-energy (VHE) neutrinos above approximately 10 Petaelectronvolts. Along with the research, Muzio will work with the Climate and Diversity Committee and others at the university to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities at both the postdoctoral and undergraduate levels. 
 
Detection of VHE neutrinos will address pressing questions in the study of ultrahigh energy cosmic rays, including how their sources are distributed, what their composition is, and if accelerators produce a substantial flux at energies at length scales inaccessible through cosmic ray observations. Importantly, neutrinos will address these questions in a hadronic interaction model-independent way, sidestepping particle physics uncertainties that plague the interpretation of cosmic ray data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this award was to perform theoretical and experimental studies to expand the multimessenger impact of in-ice radio arrays searching for ultrahigh energy neutrinos (>10 PeV). In particular, phenomenological and multimessenger studies of ultrahigh energy cosmic rays sources would be conducted to set novel observational targets for the next generation of ultrahigh energy neutrino and cosmic ray observatories. At the same time, pioneering experimental searches for ultrahigh energy neutrinos with the Askaryan Radio Array (ARA) would be conducted to both improve the sensitivity of such searches and to realize their full sensitivity. The goal of this project was also to work with departmental committees to broaden participation in physics at the undergraduate and postdoctoral levels.

 

With the support of this award, we have developed key benchmarks for the next generation of astroparticle observatories, as well as, novel multimessenger probes of the distribution of ultrahigh energy cosmic ray sources in the Universe. In particular, we have proposed novel methods of measuring this distribution using measurements of (or constraints on) the flux of ultrahigh energy neutrinos, as will be provided by in-ice radio arrays, like ARA and the Radio Neutrino Observatory in Greenland (RNO-G). With the support of this award, we have also conducted two searches (ongoing) for ultrahigh energy neutrinos with ARA. The first of these combines the improved trigger sensitivity of a phased array with the background rejection power of traditional deep, in-ice antennas. This search has already demonstrated the improved discrimination of simulated neutrinos from real background events. The results of this search will be applicable to the next-generation of in-ice radio arrays, like RNO-G and IceCube-Gen2 Radio, which share this detection paradigm. The second search leverages the full livetime of ARA to conduct the first-ever array-wide (5 station) search for ultrahigh energy neutrinos in order to realize the full sensitivity of in-ice radio arrays. This search will result in a world-leading constraint on the flux of ultrahigh energy neutrinos and lays a framework for future searches on large in-ice radio arrays, like RNO-G (35 stations) and IceCube-Gen2 Radio (361 stations).

 

Finally, we have supported significant departmental efforts to broaden participation at the postdoctoral and undergraduate levels. Through the departmental climate committee, we participated in self-assessments of department culture and policies to better understand the barriers to undergraduate and, especially, postdoctoral participation and sense of belonging in the department. We developed recommendations for actions and changes in policy to remove these barriers, a number of which were successfully implemented and more which continue to be. Additionally, mentoring of several undergraduate researchers led to successful and impactful projects in astroparticle physics.
